TEAMS HAVE PLAYED SINCE 1888
St. John's and Hopkins Have Battled in
Twenty-Four Games- Varsity
Were Victors in Nine.

Johns Hopkins and St. John's
have met on the gridiron twentyfour times since 1888. St. John's
has won twelve games, Hopkins
nine; there have been three ties and
Hopkins forfeited two games to St.
John's in years when it had no
representative on the field.
St. John's is a much older institution than Hopkins and in the
earlier years had better facilities for
putting strong teams on the field.
It has not been many years that
Hopkins has had the Homewood
field, and many can remember when
the Black and Blue practiced once
a week and played at Clifton to a
nonpaying attendance.
The hat was passed to cover expenses then.
The keen rivalry which now exists between the 'Varsity and the
Annapolis team had its inception
about 1906. Since then Hopkins
has won four games and St. John's
three. The 1907 game was a tie.
The scores from 1888 to date follow:

Sophomore-Freshman Game.

The possibility of a football game
this year between the sophomores
and the freshmen is being considered by all students interested in
athletics. The temporary blacklisting of the majority of the sophomore class is being used by them
as an argument against such a Contest, in that they claim to be unprepared through lack of freedom
to practice; but the general concensus of opinion in the University
seems to be that it is "up to" the
sophomores to go in and play the
game. What will develop is not as
yet exactly known; at any rate the
outcome of the situation is eagerly
awaited by all students.

.BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 1, 1913.

HOPKINS PLUNGING BEATS ST. JOHN'S
Annapolis Team, Unable to Withstand Taliaferro's Fierce Charges
Through Its Line, Goes Down to Defeat, 14 to 3-Tippett
and Bowers Star-Wilkinson Elected Captain.
Taliaferro opened the game by kicking off to Clark, who advanced the
ball to the 30-yard line. St. John's tried an end run, but failed. On the
second play, however, Clark made a spurt around right end for 35 yards,
but St. John's were penalized 15 yards for holding. Then McNutt punted
for 40 yards to Tippett, who was downed in midfield. Taliaferro made
four yards through the line. Brooks made two more, and on the next
play gained one. Then Hopkins was penalized five yards for being offside. On the next play Taliaferro went through the line eight yards
for first down. In two more line plays, Branham and Taliaferro netted
six yards. On the next play Taliaferro gained the four necessary to
make first down. Tippett then got away from the St. John's ends and
carried the ball seven yards. Taliaferro made first down on'a line plunge.
Brooks tore through tackle for m yards, placing the ball on the St. John's
one-yard line. Then Taliaferro crossed the goal for the first touchdown,
after five minutes and forty seconds of play. Wilkinson booted the ball
squarely between the posts. Score, 7 to 0.
Taliaferro kicked off to Heise, who advanced from the m-yard mark
until he was spilled by Bowers on the 34-yard line. St. John's gained
one yard through the line, and then failed ill a poor attempt at a forward pass. Hanver tried an end run, but was brought to earth by Wilkinson after a gain of four yards. St. John's was then forced to punt.
Tippett received, and went five yards. Hopkins then resumed a series
of line plays, Brooks and Taliaferro tearing through for first down in
three plays. Tippett broke away around the end for 12 yards, but Hopkins lost 15 yards for holding. After two line plays, which netted six
yards for Hopkins, Tippett tried a drop-kick from the 40-yard line, hut
failed. St. John's then worked a fake pass for 15 yards. Hopkins held
for one play, but on the next St. John's pulled off an end run for 20
yards. Taliaferro was taken out on account of a hurt ankle. Chunn
replaced him.
On a fumble, St. John's lost 12 yards. An end run gained nothing
for them. On the third down Clark made Jo yards. McNutt then
punted to Tippett. Wilkinson hit the line for io yards. After Brooks
had gained 12 yards by plunging-, Hopkins suffered a penalty of 15
yards for holding, and 'Selby blocked Tippett's kick just as the quarter
ended.
St. John's had the ball on Hopkins six-yard line. They tried line
plunging, but to no avail. Captain Leibensperger carried Clark back 14
yards. Heise then drop-kicked goal, making the score 7 to 3.
On the kickoff, Captain Leibensperger advanced the ball 17 yards.
Brooks hit the line for three yards, and St. John's were penalized five
yards for being offside. Chunn went through for five yards. Wilkinson lost a little, but Brooks quickly forged ahead on the next play. Chunn
then carried the ball to the 30-yard line. The Soldiers held for downs
and punted to Tippett who brought the ball back 10 yards. St. John's
seemed to hold for two plays, but Bowers tore off eight yards, and
Brooks three, before they could brace up again. They then held for
three plays, and the ball went over. McNutt punted, Tippett fumbled,
and St. John's recovered the ball on their 35-yard line. They fumbled
in return, and Tippett failed again to drop-kick successfully. Clark took
the pigskin 30 yards on an end run. St. John's tried line plunges, but
was able to gain very little. The half ended with St. John's making
an incomplete pass.
At the beginning of the third quarter Heise got away with the ball
on the kickoff, taking it 20 yards before Bowers stopped him. St. John's
failed on a fake pass, and was penalized five yards for being offside.
An end run resulted in a loss, and they punted to Hopkins 15-yard line.
On a double pass play, the Indians; favorite, Bowers made a sensational run to the St. John's 14-yard mark. Brooks and Tippett made
five yards. Taliaferro was sent in, and made four yards. He tried
the line again, and went to the four-yard line. Taliaferro gained nothing; Brooks made two yards, and Tippett crossed the goal line. Wilkinson kicked an easy goal, making the score 14 to 3.
Wilkinson kicked off to Clark. St. John's'made eight yards on the
first play, kit Hopkins braced and they gained nothing on the next.

ROOTERS DID BRILLIANT WORK
Sutton's Cheering Section in East Stand
Helped the 'Varsity Win Its Fight.
Oh, You Six-Piece Band!

One of the most attractive features of the game was the splendid
rooting of Hopkins and St. John's
admirers. The sections of the stand
that had be_n assigned to those who
cheered the teams were filled to
capacity.
Accompanied by a band of six loud
pieces, the Hopkins cohorts sang
and shouted themselves hoarse, undeterred by the bad weather.
Beginning about a half an hour
before the game was called, the
rooting was almost continuous for
two hours, the only lull coming between the two halves. Wh:n the
teams were in midfield the strains
of 'We've Got Sand in Our Makeup" and "Where, Oh \\There, Are
the Soldier Boys?" floated out encouraging-iv over the field; when
Hopkins was near the goal, there
were heard the urgent entreaties:
"We Want a Touchdown" and "Hit
'Ern Again, Hard !" And even
when St. John's had Hopkins on
the Black and Blue's two-yard line,
the 'Varsity rooters cheered to such
good effect that their goal-line was
not crossed. When a man was
hurt or brought distinction upon
himself by a spectacular run or
tackle, he was given a long ra-a-y
or a hearty hullabaloo. In fact
those "on the side of the line" distinguished themselves almost as
much as the heroes on the field.
When the whistle blew the game
to a close and it was known that
Hopkins had wiped out completely
last year's defeat, there was a display of spirit and enthusiasm such
as had never before been seen on
the Homewood grounds. Rushing
on to the field, about wo or 150
Hopkins students formed in single
file, and pulled off a weird snake
dance to the two goals. They
threw into the air their hats and
megaphones and broke out into wild
cheering. The crowd then rushed
to the clubhouse, where it stood
outsid2 of the dressing-rooms,
cheering the St. John's team and
the individual members of the Hopkins squad. Cates, Hunter and
Dorsey were given noisy yells of
approval, and the party broke up
just as night was beginning to settle
over Homewood field.
One prominent characteristic of
the rooting was the good feeling
shown by the two student bodies.
Before the game they exchanged
cheers of greeting, and after it a
hearty one of Hopkins gave St.
John's consolation. St. John's sang
"Aul Lang Syne."

Football News.

The Hopkins football team played
three games during the past fortnight, winning one out of the three.
•An account of each game follows:
Hopkins,0; W.M.C., 10.

At the beginning of the game
everything was in Hopkins favor
and it was not until we had the
ball on W. M. C.'s five-yard line
that they took a brace. It was a
very effective one, however, for before the end of the first half Patton carried the ball over Hopkins
line for a touchdown, and Baker
kicked goal.
The line bucking of W. M. C.
is the most effective encountered by
the team this year, and if it were
not for the excellent work of Substitute Bouschelle, Armstrong, Robinson and Mullen, the score would
have been much larger.
Hopkins, 30; M. A.C., 6.

The 'Varsity eleven won a brilliant victory over the Maryland
Agricultural College in the first
game for the intercollegiate series
for the State championship. It
was Hopkins game from the kickoff, and the College team were
routed at every point, only scoring
once, and that on a fluke.
Francis was the hero of the day
and his beautiful run of sixty yards
for a touchdown was the feature of
the game. Hodges played a wonderful game, and the work of Robinson, Haulenbeek and Talty also deserves much credit.
Hopkins,0; Swarthmore, 16.

All the scoring in this game was
done in the first half. The second
half was nip and tuck, and at the
end of the game the ball was in
midfield. Every one played steadily, and Robinson, Francis and
Hodges especially distinguished
themselves. Swarthmore's superiority in weight was accountable for
their victory.

BALTIMORE, MD., DEC. 1, 1913.
14 to 3.

Unable to penetrate the barrierlike strength of Hopkins line, and
bewildered by the unerring accuracy of our backfield in its
plunges through and against the
line, St. John's has tasted defeat
again at Homewood.
Every man with that true Hopkins spirit rejoices in the triumph
of the 1913 'Varsity football team.
Never have we seen a cleaner,
harder, or more. interesting game
of football than that of the team
which Thursday indelibly wrote its
name in Hopkins history.
The spectacle of that eleven, outplaying St. John's at almost every
moment, backed by the enthusiasm
of two hundred Hopkins students

The Track Team.

By ry man while at the University should try his ability in some
form of athletics. A man's college
training is not complete without it.
Especially in a college situated as
Hopkins is, without dormitories, a
man r ally gets a grzat deal more
out of college lif2 than if he had
not played on an athletic team. It
does not take time from his studies
nor lower his marks; it makes a
man more efficient for work.
Little Dr. Queed, in Harrison's
rec nt novel, makes the discovery
that the hour lost in exercise each
day does not take away from his
daily output of work—he can think
more cl:arly and work better for
having made his body physically
fit. So don't think that because
you come out for a team you are
going to flunk your physics.
At Hopkins there has been built
up in the last few years a track
team that is a credit to the University. Some can remember that
four years ago, when the time came
to choose a relay team, there were
so few mcn available that it was
a foregone conclusion who would
make the team. Last year there
were enough men for three relays
and it was not known until the last
moment who would compose the big
four, so keen was the competition.
Recent development has been due
in part to our fine Homewood track,
without doubt one of the finest
tracks in the country; in part to
the great work of the coaches who
have been with the men all the
time, tirelessly working to make a
winning team; above all it has been
due to the great spirit among the
men. Mr. England has instilled a
manly fighting spirit, yet with it a
spirit of fair sportsmanship, into
all the men, and the team is not a
group of self-interested individuals,
but an entity made up of all the
men of the squad.
The track team organization
meeting will be held on Tuesday
afternoon, December 2, at five
o'clock in the Trophy Room. Every
man in the University is invited
to be there to hear what the track
team purposes to do this, coming
season. A number of old track
team stars will attend to help us
on to a rousing beginning of another successful season.

TEAMS HAVE PLAYED SINCE 1888
St. John's and Hopkins Have Battled in
Twenty-Four Games- Varsity
Were Victors in Nine.

Johns Hopkins and St. John's
have met on the gridiron twentyfour times since 1888. St. John's
has won twelve games, Hopkins
nine; there have been three ties and
Hopkins forfeited two games to St.
John's in years when it had no
representative on the field.
St. John's is a much older institution than Hopkins and in the
earlier years had better facilities for
putting strong teams on the field.
It has not been many years that
Hopkins has had the Homewood
field, and many can remember when
the Black and Blue practiced once
a week and played at Clifton to a
nonpaying attendance.
The hat was passed to cover expenses then.
The keen rivalry which now exists between the 'Varsity and the
Annapolis team had its inception
about 1906. Since then Hopkins
has won four games and St. John's
three. The 1907 game was a tie.
The scores from 1888 to date follow:

Sophomore-Freshman Game.

The possibility of a football game
this year between the sophomores
and the freshmen is being considered by all students interested in
athletics. The temporary blacklisting of the majority of the sophomore class is being used by them
as an argument against such a Contest, in that they claim to be unprepared through lack of freedom
to practice; but the general concensus of opinion in the University
seems to be that it is "up to" the
sophomores to go in and play the
game. What will develop is not as
yet exactly known; at any rate the
outcome of the situation is eagerly
awaited by all students.

HOPKINS PLUNGING BEATS ST. JOHN'S
Annapolis Team, Unable to Withstand Taliaferro's Fierce Charges
Through Its Line, Goes Down to Defeat, 14 to 3-Tippett
and Bowers Star-Wilkinson Elected Captain.
Taliaferro opened the game by kicking off to Clark, who advanced the
ball to the 30-yard line. St. John's tried an end run, but failed. On the
second play, however, Clark made a spurt around right end for 35 yards,
but St. John's were penalized 15 yards for holding. Then McNutt punted
for 40 yards to Tippett, who was downed in midfield. Taliaferro made
four yards through the line. Brooks made two more, and on the next
play gained one. Then Hopkins was penalized five yards for being offside. On the next play Taliaferro went through the line eight yards
for first down. In two more line plays, Branham and Taliaferro netted
six yards. On the next play Taliaferro gained the four necessary to
make first down. Tippett then got away from the St. John's ends and
carried the ball seven yards. Taliaferro made first down on'a line plunge.
Brooks tore through tackle for m yards, placing the ball on the St. John's
one-yard line. Then Taliaferro crossed the goal for the first touchdown,
after five minutes and forty seconds of play. Wilkinson booted the ball
squarely between the posts. Score, 7 to 0.
Taliaferro kicked off to Heise, who advanced from the m-yard mark
until he was spilled by Bowers on the 34-yard line. St. John's gained
one yard through the line, and then failed ill a poor attempt at a forward pass. Hanver tried an end run, but was brought to earth by Wilkinson after a gain of four yards. St. John's was then forced to punt.
Tippett received, and went five yards. Hopkins then resumed a series
of line plays, Brooks and Taliaferro tearing through for first down in
three plays. Tippett broke away around the end for 12 yards, but Hopkins lost 15 yards for holding. After two line plays, which netted six
yards for Hopkins, Tippett tried a drop-kick from the 40-yard line, hut
failed. St. John's then worked a fake pass for 15 yards. Hopkins held
for one play, but on the next St. John's pulled off an end run for 20
yards. Taliaferro was taken out on account of a hurt ankle. Chunn
replaced him.
On a fumble, St. John's lost 12 yards. An end run gained nothing
for them. On the third down Clark made Jo yards. McNutt then
punted to Tippett. Wilkinson hit the line for io yards. After Brooks
had gained 12 yards by plunging-, Hopkins suffered a penalty of 15
yards for holding, and 'Selby blocked Tippett's kick just as the quarter
ended.
St. John's had the ball on Hopkins six-yard line. They tried line
plunging, but to no avail. Captain Leibensperger carried Clark back 14
yards. Heise then drop-kicked goal, making the score 7 to 3.
On the kickoff, Captain Leibensperger advanced the ball 17 yards.
Brooks hit the line for three yards, and St. John's were penalized five
yards for being offside. Chunn went through for five yards. Wilkinson lost a little, but Brooks quickly forged ahead on the next play. Chunn
then carried the ball to the 30-yard line. The Soldiers held for downs
and punted to Tippett who brought the ball back 10 yards. St. John's
seemed to hold for two plays, but Bowers tore off eight yards, and
Brooks three, before they could brace up again. They then held for
three plays, and the ball went over. McNutt punted, Tippett fumbled,
and St. John's recovered the ball on their 35-yard line. They fumbled
in return, and Tippett failed again to drop-kick successfully. Clark took
the pigskin 30 yards on an end run. St. John's tried line plunges, but
was able to gain very little. The half ended with St. John's making
an incomplete pass.
At the beginning of the third quarter Heise got away with the ball
on the kickoff, taking it 20 yards before Bowers stopped him. St. John's
failed on a fake pass, and was penalized five yards for being offside.
An end run resulted in a loss, and they punted to Hopkins 15-yard line.
On a double pass play, the Indians; favorite, Bowers made a sensational run to the St. John's 14-yard mark. Brooks and Tippett made
five yards. Taliaferro was sent in, and made four yards. He tried
the line again, and went to the four-yard line. Taliaferro gained nothing; Brooks made two yards, and Tippett crossed the goal line. Wilkinson kicked an easy goal, making the score 14 to 3.
Wilkinson kicked off to Clark. St. John's'made eight yards on the
first play, kit Hopkins braced and they gained nothing on the next.

ROOTERS DID BRILLIANT WORK
Sutton's Cheering Section in East Stand
Helped the 'Varsity Win Its Fight.
Oh, You Six-Piece Band!

One of the most attractive features of the game was the splendid
rooting of Hopkins and St. John's
admirers. The sections of the stand
that had be_n assigned to those who
cheered the teams were filled to
capacity.
Accompanied by a band of six loud
pieces, the Hopkins cohorts sang
and shouted themselves hoarse, undeterred by the bad weather.
Beginning about a half an hour
before the game was called, the
rooting was almost continuous for
two hours, the only lull coming between the two halves. Wh:n the
teams were in midfield the strains
of 'We've Got Sand in Our Makeup" and "Where, Oh \\There, Are
the Soldier Boys?" floated out encouraging-iv over the field; when
Hopkins was near the goal, there
were heard the urgent entreaties:
"We Want a Touchdown" and "Hit
'Ern Again, Hard !" And even
when St. John's had Hopkins on
the Black and Blue's two-yard line,
the 'Varsity rooters cheered to such
good effect that their goal-line was
not crossed. When a man was
hurt or brought distinction upon
himself by a spectacular run or
tackle, he was given a long ra-a-y
or a hearty hullabaloo. In fact
those "on the side of the line" distinguished themselves almost as
much as the heroes on the field.
When the whistle blew the game
to a close and it was known that
Hopkins had wiped out completely
last year's defeat, there was a display of spirit and enthusiasm such
as had never before been seen on
the Homewood grounds. Rushing
on to the field, about wo or 150
Hopkins students formed in single
file, and pulled off a weird snake
dance to the two goals. They
threw into the air their hats and
megaphones and broke out into wild
cheering. The crowd then rushed
to the clubhouse, where it stood
outsid2 of the dressing-rooms,
cheering the St. John's team and
the individual members of the Hopkins squad. Cates, Hunter and
Dorsey were given noisy yells of
approval, and the party broke up
just as night was beginning to settle
over Homewood field.
One prominent characteristic of
the rooting was the good feeling
shown by the two student bodies.
Before the game they exchanged
cheers of greeting, and after it a
hearty one of Hopkins gave St.
John's consolation. St. John's sang
"Aul Lang Syne."

Football News.

The Hopkins football team played
three games during the past fortnight, winning one out of the three.
•An account of each game follows:
Hopkins,0; W.M.C., 10.

At the beginning of the game
everything was in Hopkins favor
and it was not until we had the
ball on W. M. C.'s five-yard line
that they took a brace. It was a
very effective one, however, for before the end of the first half Patton carried the ball over Hopkins
line for a touchdown, and Baker
kicked goal.
The line bucking of W. M. C.
is the most effective encountered by
the team this year, and if it were
not for the excellent work of Substitute Bouschelle, Armstrong, Robinson and Mullen, the score would
have been much larger.
Hopkins, 30; M. A.C., 6.

The 'Varsity eleven won a brilliant victory over the Maryland
Agricultural College in the first
game for the intercollegiate series
for the State championship. It
was Hopkins game from the kickoff, and the College team were
routed at every point, only scoring
once, and that on a fluke.
Francis was the hero of the day
and his beautiful run of sixty yards
for a touchdown was the feature of
the game. Hodges played a wonderful game, and the work of Robinson, Haulenbeek and Talty also deserves much credit.
Hopkins,0; Swarthmore, 16.

All the scoring in this game was
done in the first half. The second
half was nip and tuck, and at the
end of the game the ball was in
midfield. Every one played steadily, and Robinson, Francis and
Hodges especially distinguished
themselves. Swarthmore's superiority in weight was accountable for
their victory.

Unable to penetrate the barrierlike strength of Hopkins line, and
bewildered by the unerring accuracy of our backfield in its
plunges through and against the
line, St. John's has tasted defeat
again at Homewood.
Every man with that true Hopkins spirit rejoices in the triumph
of the 1913 'Varsity football team.
Never have we seen a cleaner,
harder, or more. interesting game
of football than that of the team
which Thursday indelibly wrote its
name in Hopkins history.
The spectacle of that eleven, outplaying St. John's at almost every
moment, backed by the enthusiasm
of two hundred Hopkins students
standing in the rain, was the succ:ssful climax of a season that had
not b:en a primrose path. But it
is enough that Hopkins beat St.
John's.
THE NEN,vs-LETTP,R takes the responsibility of giving to the team
of 1913, as from Hopkins undergraduates, a vote of deep gratitude
for what it has accomplished. To
Coall Jack Cates we give our
thanks for half a season's excellent
service. We hope that he will
handle the squad again next season.
To Manager John L. Dorsey is also
due thanks for his untiring efforts
to successfully carry on the business affairs of the team. To Captain Ray Leibensperger, tackle, we
extend congratulations, and to his
mate on the other side of the line,
Captain-elect Paul Wilkinson, we
wish a most successful season in

The Track Team.

By ry man while at the University should try his ability in some
form of athletics. A man's college
training is not complete without it.
Especially in a college situated as
Hopkins is, without dormitories, a
man r ally gets a grzat deal more
out of college lif2 than if he had
not played on an athletic team. It
does not take time from his studies
nor lower his marks; it makes a
man more efficient for work.
Little Dr. Queed, in Harrison's
rec nt novel, makes the discovery
that the hour lost in exercise each
day does not take away from his
daily output of work—he can think
more cl:arly and work better for
having made his body physically
fit. So don't think that because
you come out for a team you are
going to flunk your physics.
At Hopkins there has been built
up in the last few years a track
team that is a credit to the University. Some can remember that
four years ago, when the time came
to choose a relay team, there were
so few mcn available that it was
a foregone conclusion who would
make the team. Last year there
were enough men for three relays
and it was not known until the last
moment who would compose the big
four, so keen was the competition.
Recent development has been due
in part to our fine Homewood track,
without doubt one of the finest
tracks in the country; in part to
the great work of the coaches who
have been with the men all the
time, tirelessly working to make a
winning team; above all it has been
due to the great spirit among the
men. Mr. England has instilled a
manly fighting spirit, yet with it a
spirit of fair sportsmanship, into
all the men, and the team is not a
group of self-interested individuals,
but an entity made up of all the
men of the squad.
The track team organization
meeting will be held on Tuesday
afternoon, December 2, at five
o'clock in the Trophy Room. Every
man in the University is invited
to be there to hear what the track
team purposes to do this, coming
season. A number of old track
team stars will attend to help us
on to a rousing beginning of another successful season.
